Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Micro and Nanoscale Thin Film Pyroelectric Materials via Strain Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
As thermal energy is ubiquitous and abundant, many materials, structures, and strategies have been studied and developed to harness heat energy. In applications where self-powered devices are preferred (for example, bio-implanted devices and extraterrestrial field robots), the ability to harvest the waste thermal energy from the ambient environment by small devices is needed. Micro and nanoscale pyroelectric materials and devices are one possible solution, as they can convert small and irregular temperature fluctuations into electricity. However, their extremely low power density is a major obstacle preventing practical applications. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award supports research on designing, fabricating and achieving technologically useful micro and nanoscale thermal-to-electrical energy conversion materials and devices by elastic strain engineering. The research has potentially broad impacts on the development of environmentally-friendly thermal devices for sustainable energy harvesting. This research has potential to benefit the US economy in the sector of clean energy. In addition, the researchers will to reach out to K-12 students at local high schools through the demonstration of nanodevices for energy conversion.

The objective of this research is to explore a potentially transformative micro and nanoscale pyroelectric hybrid thin film material with giant thermoelectric Figure of Merit. The innovative key concept is the transfer of the ultrafast thermal phase transition of strongly correlated oxides with colossal lattice dilation/contraction to conventional pyroelectric material. The material's pyroelectric coefficient is expected to be two to three orders of magnitude higher than conventional pyroelectrics. Specific aims are to demonstrate the fabrication of high-quality pyroelectric VO2/ZnO hybrid thin film system, and characterize the high Figure of Merit metrics in these materials and structures. The PIs will fabricate the materials and structures by radio frequency sputtering and optical lithography, and test the individual components' pyroelectric properties and the hybrid material's synthetic functionalities and performances. The PIs will explore the upper limit of the hybrid's high materials metrics in terms of pyroelectric coefficient, Figure of Merit, and power density. These activities will be designed and guided by computational modeling efforts. The intellectual significance of the work includes: new understanding on the unique design and working mechanism of pyroelectric materials; quantitative understanding and modeling of coupled processes including ultrafast phase transition, heat flow, strain/stress, and electrical polarization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When self-powered devices are mandatory or preferred under certain circumstances, the ability to harvest the waste thermal energy from ambient environment by a greatly reduced size of devices compared to our daily-use heat engines is demanded. For thermal-electrical energy conversion, two major concepts - thermoelectrics and pyroelectrics - are commonly applied. Though thermoelectric nanostructures may outperform their bulk forms in terms of energy conversion efficiency, the great lack of periodically and spatially distributed temperature gradient at micro and nanoscale from ambient environment heavily limits the application of thermoelectric micro and nanodevices for waste energy harvesting. A more common form of the thermal energy at micro and nanoscale manifested in our daily life is the thermal fluctuation at the time domain. To harvest such temperature fluctuation energy, micro and nanoscale pyroelectric materials and devices are favorable. However, in the past, often pyroelectric nanowires or thin films generate very limited voltage and power, which could be consumed and exhausted by the energy collection circuits and pyroelectric materials themselves prior to reaching the energy storage devices. Among several parameters, the relatively low pyroelectric coefficient is a fundamental reason to the poor performance of the pyroelectric micro and nanodevice. This NSF project supports our research on exploring potentially transformative micro and nanoscale pyroelectric hybrid materials with giant thermoelectric Figure of Merit via modifying materials’ pyroelectric coefficients by dynamic strain engineering. It was proposed that the giant thermal strain in VO2 can be translated to the as-coated pyroelectric material tuning the secondary pyroelectric component and leading to giant pyroelectric coefficient. Over this project, we have experimentally realized novel hybrid pyroelectric materials (VO2/CdS, VO2/ZnO) with orders of magnitude increased thermoelectric Figure of Merit relative to the-state-of-art at moderate temperature regime. We have learned how to experimentally develop the key components of individual pyroelectric device and large scale ones. Fundamentally new knowledge on the synthesis and processing of strongly correlated nanoscale materials, pyroelectric films and their hybrids have been received during the implementation of the proposed research objective. Via both simulations and experiments, we have received deep quantitative understanding on the roles of materials interfaces on the effectiveness of thermal elastic strain engineering of functional materials via strongly correlated oxides. The research suggests the feasibility of the development of environmentally-friendly thermal devices for sustainable energy harvesting at nanoscale. In addition, significant public outreach to K-12 students and the training of two high school students from minority groups focused on the research results supported by this award have been achieved.
